questions.text: All of the followings are bipolar neurons, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Classification of Neurons by Number of Processes

  • Unipolar: One process; e.g., mesencephalic nucleus.
  • Pseudo-unipolar: One process that bifurcates; e.g., sensory ganglia or spinal ganglia.
  • Bipolar: Two processes; e.g., spiral and vestibular ganglia, bipolar neurons of retina, olfactory epithelium.
  • Multipolar: Multiple processes; e.g., neurons in cerebrum and cerebellum.

Key takeaways:

questions.text: Which of the following neuroglia cells are involved in Multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple Sclerosis

  • Definition: A debilitating, degenerative disorder of unknown cause.
  • Characteristics: Multifocal demyelination throughout the white matter of the CNS.
  • Cell Involvement: Primarily affects oligodendrocytes, the neuroglia cells responsible for myelination.
  • Location of Oligodendrocytes: Found in clusters around neurons in gray matter and along myelinated nerve fibers in white matter.
  • Function: Oligodendrocytes form the myelin sheath around axons in the CNS, similar to the function of Schwann cells in the peripheral nervous system.

Key takeaways : Multiple sclerosis is a debilitating disorder characterized by multifocal CNS demyelination due to the involvement of oligodendrocytes, which form the myelin sheath around axons.

questions.text: Who is known as Father of Anatomy?
questions.solution:
• Father of Anatomy: Herophilus
  • Father of Modern Anatomy: Vesalius
  • Father of Surgery: Sushruta
  • Father of Medicine: Hippocrates
  • Father of Histology: Marcelo Malpighi
  • Father of Genetics: Gregor Johann Mendel
  • Term Anatomy was coined by: Aristotle
  • First scientist to dissect the human body: Herophilus
  • Prince of Physicians: Claudius Galen

choices.text: Both the arms by the side of body

questions.text: All of the following is true about anatomical position of body, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Positions of body:

  • Anatomical position:
    • When a person is standing straight with eyes looking forwards,
    • Both arms by the side of body,
    • Palms facing forwards,
    • Both feet together,
    • The position is anatomical position.
  • Supine position:
    • When a person is lying on her/his back, arms by the side, palms facing upwards and feet put together, the position is supine position.
  • Prone position:
    • Person lying on his/her face, chest and abdomen is said to be in prone position.

Key takeaways :

In the anatomical position, the body stands straight with eyes looking forward, arms at the sides, palms facing forward, and feet together.

questions.text: All of the following are supenumerary bones, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Accessory (Supernumerary) Bones

  • Presence: Not always present; occur as ununited epiphyses from extra centers of ossification.
  • Examples:
    • Sutural Bones
    • Os Trigonum: Lateral tubercle of the talus.
    • Os Vesalianum: Tuberosity of the 5th metatarsal.
  • Medicolegal Implications: May be mistaken for fractures; typically bilateral with smooth surfaces and no callus formation.

Key takeaways:

  • Rider's bone is heterotopic bone. It is develps in adductor longus muscle in horse riders.

questions.text: The coracoid process of scapula is an example of which of the following type of the epiphysis?
questions.solution:
Epiphysis:

  • The ends and tips of a bone which ossify from secondary centres are called epiphyses.
  • These are of the following types.
  • Pressure epiphysis:
    • It is articular and takes part in transmission of the weight.
    • Examples: head of femur; lower end of radius, etc.
  • Traction epiphysis:
    • It is nonarticular and does not take part in the transmission of the weight.
    • It always provides attachment to one or more tendons which exert a traction on the epiphysis. It ossify later than the pressure epiphyses.
    • Examples: trochanters of femur and tubercles of humerus
  • Atavistic epiphysis:
    • It is phylogenetically an independent bone which in man becomes fused to another bone.
    • Examples: coracoid process of scapula and os trigonum or lateral tubercle of talus.
  • Aberrant epiphysis:
    • It is not always present.
    • Examples: epiphysis at the head of the first metacarpal and at the base of other metacarpal bones.

Key takeaways :

The epiphysis refers to the ends of a bone that ossify from secondary centers, with types including pressure, traction, atavistic, and aberrant epiphyses.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of bipennate muscle?
questions.solution:
Oblique Muscle Arrangements

  • Muscle Structure: When fasciculi are oblique to the line of pull, muscles may be triangular or pennate (feather-like), enhancing power but reducing the range of movement.
  • Types of Oblique Arrangements:
    • Triangular: e.g., Temporalis, Adductor Longus
    • Unipennate: e.g., Flexor Pollicis Longus, Extensor Digitorum Longus, Peroneus Tertius, Palmar Interossei
    • Bipennate: e.g., Rectus Femoris, Dorsal Interossei, Peroneus Longus, Flexor Hallucis Longus
    • Multipennate: e.g., Subscapularis, Deltoid (Acromial Fibers)
    • Circumpennate: e.g., Tibialis Anterior

Key takeaways:

questions.text: In case of pregnancy which of the following condition occurs in the uterus?
questions.solution:
• Atrophy: The muscles which are not used for long times become thin and weak. This is called disuse atrophy. Muscular 'wasting' (reduction in size) is a feature of lower motor neuron paralysis and generalized debility.
  • Hypertrophy: Adequate or excessive use of particular muscles causes their better development, or even hypertrophy
  • Hyperplasia: Increase in number of smooth muscle fibres. Usually occurs in uterus during pregnancy.
  • Hypoplasia: It is the incomplete development or underdevelopment of an organ or tissue. Hence, organs or tissue affected by hypoplasia have a below average number of cells. There are different types of hypoplasia, depending on what tissue is affected.

Key takeaways : Hypertrophy refers to the increase in the size of existing muscle fibers due to use, while hyperplasia refers to the increase in the number of muscle fibers, often occurring in the uterus during pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of resistance vessels?
questions.solution:
Functional Classification of Blood Vessels

  1. Conducting Vessels:
    • Large arteries (elastic arteries) that accommodate high-pressure blood flow and help maintain blood pressure.
  2. Distributing Vessels:
    • Medium-sized arteries (muscular arteries) that distribute blood to specific body regions and organs, controlling flow with muscular contractions.
  3. Resistance Vessels:
    • Arterioles and precapillary sphincters that regulate blood flow and pressure by constricting or dilating, influencing resistance in the circulatory system.
  4. Exchange Vessels:
    • Capillaries, sinusoids, and postcapillary venules that facilitate the exchange of nutrients, gases, and waste products between blood and tissues.
  5. Reservoir (Capacitance) Vessels:
    • Larger venules and veins that store blood and regulate its return to the heart, adapting to varying blood volume.
  6. Shunts:
    • Various types of anastomoses that provide alternative pathways for blood flow, allowing for regulation and flexibility in circulation.

Key takeaways :

capacitance) vessels: Including larger venules

Resistance vessels: Including arterioles

questions.text: Which of the following is not an end artery?
questions.solution:
End Arteries

  • Definition: End arteries are arteries that do not anastomose with their neighboring arteries, meaning they have no alternative blood supply.
  • Examples:
    • Central artery of the retina
    • Labyrinthine artery of the internal ear
    • Central branches of cerebral arteries
    • Vasa recta of mesenteric arteries
    • Arteries of the spleen, kidney, lungs, and metaphyses of long bones
  • Clinical Significance: Occlusion of an end artery can lead to serious nutritional disturbances and tissue death. For example, occlusion of the central artery of the retina can result in blindness.

Key takeaways :

  • End arteries are arteries that do not anastomose with neighboring arteries, and their occlusion can lead to serious tissue damage, such as blindness from the central artery of the retina.

questions.text: All of the followings are examples of primary cartilaginous joint, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Primary cartilaginous joints:

  • Also known as synchondrosis, or hyaline cartilage joints.
  • The bones are united by a plate of hyaline cartilage that the joint is immovable and strong.
  • These joints are temporary in nature because after a certain age the cartilaginous plate is replaced by bone (synostosis).
  • Examples:
    • Joint between epiphysis and diaphysis of a growing long bone
    • Spheno-occipital joint
    • First chondrosternal joint
    • Costochondral joints
  • Costovertebral joint is plane variety of synovial joint.

Key takeaways:

choices.text: Ball and socket variety of synovial joint

questions.text: Incudomalleolar joint is which of the following type of joint?
questions.solution:
• Saddle (sellar) joints:
  • Articular surfaces are reciprocally
  • Following free movements are permitted:
    • Flexion and extension around the transverse axis.
    • Abduction and adduction around the anteroposterior axis.
    • Combination of movements produces circumduction.
  • Conjunct rotation occurs around a third axis; however, cannot occur independently.

Key takeaways: Articular surfaces of saddle joints are reciprocally concavoconvex,

Examples: First carpometacarpal joint

  • Sternoclavicular joint
  • Calcaneocuboid joint
  • Incudomalleolar joint

questions.text: What is the type of the X chromosome?
questions.solution:
Morphological types of chromosome:

  • Depending upon the location of centromere, the chromosomes are classified into four types.
  • Metacentric: Centromere is located in the middle.
  • Submetacentric: Centromere is located close to the middle.
  • Acrocentric: Centromere is located close to the end of chromosome.
  • Telocentric: Centromere is located at the end of the chromosome.

Key takeaways :

The epiphysis refers to the ends of a bone that ossify from secondary centers, with types including pressure, traction, atavistic, and aberrant epiphyses. Each type has specific characteristics and functions, contributing to bone development and attachment for tendons.

questions.text: Which of the follwing is not an example of autosomal dominant inheritance?
questions.solution:
• Autosomal dominant inheritance
    • Marfan's syndrome
    • Achondroplasia
    • Brachydactyly
    • Neurofibromatosis
    • Huntigton's disease
    • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Autosomal recessive inheritance
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Inborn errors of metabolism
    • Hemoglobinopathies, e.g., sickle cell anemia and thalassemia.
  • X-linked dominant inheritance
    • Vitamin-D resistant rickets
    • Hypophosphatemia
    • Xg blood group
  • X-linked recessive inheritance
    • Hemophilia
    • Colour blindness
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Duchenne muscular dystrophy
  • Y-linked inheritance
    • Hypertrichosis
    • Webbed toes
    • Porcupine man
  • Multifactorial inheritance:
    • Cleft lip
    • Cleft palate
    • Club foot
    • Congenital dislocation of hip
    • Congenital heart disease.

Key takeaways :

Inborn errors of metabolism, as they are typically inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. In contrast, examples of autosomal dominant inheritance include Marfan syndrome, neurofibromatosis, and Huntington's disease. Therefore, inborn errors of metabolism are not correct examples of autosomal dominant inheritance.

questions.text: Which of the follwing numerical abnormality is seen in Edward syndrome is?
questions.solution:
Chromosomal Abnormalities

  • Down's Syndrome (Trisomy 21): Three copies of chromosome 21; karyotype 47XY +21. Characteristics: Distinctive facial features, developmental delays.
  • Patau's Syndrome (Trisomy 13): Three copies of chromosome 13. Characteristics: Severe intellectual disability, organ defects, early mortality.
  • Edward's Syndrome (Trisomy 18): Three copies of chromosome 18. Characteristics: Growth deficiencies, heart defects, high mortality rate.
  • Klinefelter's Syndrome (XXY): Found only in males; nondisjunction during gametogenesis results in 47 chromosomes. Characteristics: Infertility, gynecomastia, and reduced testosterone levels.
  • Turner's Syndrome (45XO): Found only in females; loss of one X chromosome leads to a karyotype of 45X. Characteristics: Short stature, infertility, and heart defects.
  • Triple X Syndrome (47XXX): Fertilization of an XX oocyte by an X sperm; phenotypically female with two Barr bodies. Characteristics: May have no significant abnormalities, taller than average.

Key takeaways :

Chromosomal abnormalities include Down's (Trisomy 21), Patau's (Trisomy 13), Edward's (Trisomy 18), Klinefelter's (XXY), Turner's (45XO), and Triple X (47XXX) syndromes, each characterized by distinct physical and developmental traits.
